issues.text: Whether the challenge made by the appellants against the validity of the demand notices issued against them by the respondent is barred by res judicata by virtue of the decision of this Court in the earlier case?

anchor.surface_text: The first point which falls for our decision in these appeals is one of res judicata. The High Court has held that

issues.text: Does the decision on tax liability for a particular year operate as res judicata in respect of the liability for a subsequent year?

anchor.surface_text: The question in the present appeals, however, is somewhat different. ... Where the liability of a tax for a particular year is considered and decided does the decision for that particular year operate as res judicata in respect of the liability for a subsequent year ?

issues.text: Does the principle of constructive res judicata apply to petitions under Art. 32 or Art. 226 where the dispute raised is in respect of a year different from the year involved in a prior dispute decided by this Court?

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals, the question which arises directly for our decision is does the principle of constructive res judicata apply to petitions under Art. 32 or Art. 226 where the dispute raised is in respect of a year different from the year involved in a prior dispute decided by this Court ?

issues.text: Whether the levy authorised to be imposed by the Act and the Rules framed thereunder violates the fundamental rights guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(f) of the Constitution?

holdings.text: The general principle of res judicata applies to writ petitions filed under Article 32 or Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, there can be nodoubt that the general principle of res judicata applies to writ petitions filed under Art. 32 or Art. 226. It is necessary to emphasise that the applic

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents like Pandit M.S.M. Sharma v. Dr. Shree Krishna Sinha and Daryao v. State of U.P.; principle regulates assertion of fundamental rights without impairing them.

holdings.text: A decision on tax liability for a particular year does not operate as res judicata for liability in subsequent years as they constitute distinct causes of action.

anchor.surface_text: Where the liability of a tax for a particular year is considered and decided does the decision for that particular year operate as res judicata in respect of the liability for a subsequent year ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinct annual liabilities; follows English precedents like Society of Medical Officers of Health and Gaffoor; public interest against estoppels in recurring tax assessments.

holdings.text: The principle of constructive res judicata under Section 11 CPC does not apply to writ petitions under Article 32 or 226 where the dispute concerns a different tax year from prior proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: does the principle of constructive res judicata apply to petitions under Art. 32 or Art. 226 where the dispute raised is in respect of a year different from the year involved

holdings.reasoning_summary: Artificial doctrine not suited to writs; different years, new grounds; Art.141 binds as precedent anyway.

holdings.text: The levy of coal tax authorised by the Act and Rules does not violate fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we are not satisfied that this decision can assist the appellants at all, because the nature of the statutory provisions and the Rules

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Moopil Nair; Rules 3-10 provide quasi-judicial procedure with objection opportunity based on assessee-supplied data.

holdings.text: The increase in coal tax rate from 3 pies to 9 pies per ton is invalid for lack of previous sanction of the Provincial Government under Section 51(2) of the 1920 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, inclined to accept the appellants construction of s. 51 2 . That being so, it is necessary to enquire whether the imposition of the tax 9 pies

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'First imposition' includes rate increases; notifications show no prior sanction, only initial 3 pies sanctioned; contemporaneous s.79(xv) intent.

holdings.text: The respondent cannot reopen past assessments finalised under Rule 10 of the Coal Tax Rules to demand additional tax on exported coal.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of Rule 10, it is difficult to hold that the respondent is entitled to reopen assessments already made and rendered final under the said Rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 10 confers finality on Chairman's or Board's decisions; no reopening provision like Income Tax ss.34/35; finality binds both parties.

holdings.text: The appeals and writ petitions are allowed; respondent restrained from recovering tax above 3 pies per ton or additional tax on already assessed years.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals and the writ petitions are allowed and an appropriate direction or order is issued restraining the respondent from recovering the tax

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on res judicata, s.51(2) sanction, and Rule 10 finality.

anchor.surface_text: In that connection, the learned Chief Justice has referred to an earlier decision of this Court in Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen, 1953 SCR 154. where it has been laid down that the principle underlying res judicata is applicable in respect of a question which has been raised and decided after full contest, even though the first Tribunal which decided the matter may have no jurisdiction to try the subsequent suit

precedents.case_name: Raj Lakshmi Dasi v. Banamali Sen
precedents.cited_proposition: res judicata applies even if first tribunal lacked jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Daryao v. The State of P. 1962  1  SCR 574.

anchor.surface_text: The question about the applicability of the doctrine of res judicata to the petitions filed under Art. 32 came before this Court in another form in Daryao v. The State of P. 1962  1  SCR 574., and in that case it has been held that where the petition under Art. 226 is considered on the merits as a contested matter and dismissed by the High Court, the decision pronounced is binding on the parties

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court writ dismissal on merits bars subsequent writ petition under Art. 32

Commissioner of Taxation 1926 A.C. 155 In that case, the question which arose for decision was about the deduction claimable under the relevant provision of the Land Tax Assessment Act, 1916  Aust.  Upon the assessment for 1919-20, the Commissioner allowed only one deduction of 5, 000 lbs.

anchor.surface_text: Lord Radcliffe had occasion to return to the same subject again in Gaffoor Income-tax Commissioner 1961 2 W.L.R. 794 Speaking for the Privy Council, Lord Radcliffe considered the problem of the application of res judicata to taxation cases, examined it in detail and came to the conclusion that the said doctrine did not apply to tax cases in the sense that the decision for the levy of a tax for one year does not operate as res judicata
